paper: Learning to Reject Low-Quality Explanations via User Feedback

alignment.note: The AI review shows very high alignment on the paper's strengths but misses most weaknesses raised by human reviewers, such as the biased baseline comparison, similarity to prior work, and scalability concerns. The AI instead raises several unique methodological weaknesses, like the assumption of label preservation during data augmentation and the modest performance on the human-annotated dataset.

The AI review perfectly covers all strengths but has only moderate coverage of weaknesses, missing human concerns about biased comparisons, conceptual novelty, and the faithfulness vs. plausibility debate. Conversely, the AI introduces several major weaknesses not raised by humans, such as the lack of theoretical grounding and the focus on proxy metrics over user outcomes.

The AI review aligns closely with human feedback on strengths and covers most weaknesses, though with some polarity shifts due to incorporating paper revisions (e.g., citing LIME robustness as a strength where humans noted its absence). The AI misses specific conceptual critiques regarding the distinction between faithfulness and plausibility, the loss of information in Likert-to-binary conversion, and the assumption of expert ground-truth knowledge.

The AI review provides excellent coverage of the strengths but only moderate coverage of the weaknesses. It misses several key human concerns, such as the method's similarity to the PASTA baseline and the biased experimental comparison, while raising valid methodological points not mentioned by humans, like the modest gains on the human-annotated dataset.
